III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff member was reported to be sleeping on shift. During this
time, a youth touched another youth on the neck while the youth
was asleep. Youth called out to the staff member to see if they
were awake. The staff member asked youth not to tell anyone that
they were sleeping.
Investigation On 10/03/2023 a telephone conversation was held with the
Complainant. No additional information was disclosed.
On 10/05/2023 and 10/11/23 an in-person meeting was held with
VP of Residential Services. VP confirmed that he was familiar
with Youth A, Youth B and Staff 1 but was not aware (or recalled)
any incident where the youth reported Staff 1 was sleeping on
shift or when Staff 1 was issued disciplinary action due to sleeping
at work. On 11/08/2023 a telephone call was made to VP of
Residential Services. VP recalled that Staff 1 worked midnights
and was permanently laid off from Vassar House in April 2023.
Contact number for Staff 1 was provided.
On 10/11/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Chief
Administrator at CFC. CA denied knowledge of a report that
Staff 1 was sleeping on shift.
On 10/25/2023 a telephone call was made to Dad 1 to speak with
Youth A. Dad 1 answered and advised that she was not home
and to call again later in the evening to speak with her.
Attempts to interview Youth A were made on 10/25/23 via
telephone and text message. Dad 1 advised Youth A did not want
to speak with DHHS staff.
On 10/26/2023 a video interview was held with Youth B. Youth B
confirmed she was previously placed at Vassar House. She
denied recalling any staff sleeping at work while she was placed at
the facility. Youth B was specifically asked if she recalled working
with Staff 1. She responded she “kind of” recalled Staff 1 but could
not remember if she was male or female or black or white. She
ended by reiterating she did not recall any staff sleeping while on
shift when she was placed at Vassar House.
2

On 11/08/2023 a telephone call was made to Staff 1. She
confirmed she was a former employee of Vassar House and
primarily worked the midnight shift. Staff 1 did not recall which
unit she worked in and denied she ever slept while working
midnights. Staff 1 stated she would not hesitate to request a
break from her supervisor if she was feeling tired. Staff 1 further
denied working with Youth A and Youth B and getting “caught”
sleeping. She denied she ever asked a youth to not advise
supervision that she was sleep.
Documents Reviewed
10/02/2023 Social Work Contact from DCWL Consultant 2 -
Youth A was interviewed by phone on 10/2/2023. Youth A
reported at first Youth B had helped her settle into the facility, but
she then started to be rude. A situation with Youth B happened in
the early morning hours just before wake-up. Youth A woke when
she felt something on her neck. At first, she thought it was her
braid but realized Youth B was leaning over her. Youth B had
gotten out of her bed and was walking around the unit. Youth A
sat up in bed and put her hands in her lap. She then woke Staff 1
up. Staff 1 had something like a head band partially over her eyes
to block the light. Youth A said she called out to Staff 1, and she
mumbled something. Youth A then asked if she was awake. Youth
A reported Staff 1 responded by stating she was awake. Youth A
then told Staff 1 what happened. Youth A reported Staff 1 told the
treatment leader what happened. Youth A stated Staff 1 told her
that Youth B was trying to get her in trouble. Staff 1 also told
Youth A not to tell anyone she was sleeping so she did not get in
trouble. Youth A reports she has seen Staff 1 leaning back in her
chair at other times, but she was not sure if she was slept or not.
Wolverine Human Services Supervision/Line of Sight Policy -
Wolverine Human Services’ policy is to have a minimum of one
staff member maintaining “Line of Sight” with youth when in direct
supervision. The appropriate staff to client ratio varies between
site locations and is determined by the program and contract
requirements.
Human Resources file of Staff 1: No documentation of
disciplinary action due to sleeping on shift. Staff 1 was
permanently laid off April 2023.
Analysis After the completion of the investigation, there was not sufficient
evidence to find that the agency was not in compliance with
licensing rule 41019 (C). Youth A declined to be interviewed,
3

Youth B denied any knowledge of a staff sleeping and Staff 1
denied that she had ever been sleeping during any shift at work.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
